unnormalised: Heart health, yaar, it's something we all need to take seriously, especially with our lifestyles these days. I mean, seriously, look around - everyone's stressed, eating junk, and glued to their phones. Dr. Rajesh Khanna at AIIMS, Delhi, was just telling me that cases of heart disease are climbing, even among the younger crowd. He mentioned something about how high cholesterol levels are becoming a norm. He recommended a yearly checkup for anyone above 30, just to be on the safe side. Plus, he stressed the importance of getting some exercise – even a 30-minute walk can make a huge difference, he said.

unnormalised: Speaking of checkups, my uncle had a pretty scary experience recently. He felt some chest pain and just brushed it off as gas, you know, the usual. But thankfully, my aunt insisted he see a doctor. Turns out, he had a blockage in one of his arteries. He ended up needing an angioplasty. The whole thing cost him around Rs. 2.5 lakh at Fortis Hospital, Gurgaon. Scary stuff! He's all good now, but it was a real wake-up call for the whole family.

unnormalised: Now, I'm no doctor, but I've been doing some reading up on this stuff. Apparently, there are different types of heart problems. Some are genetic, some are caused by lifestyle, and some are just plain bad luck. I saw something about "LVH" (Left Ventricular Hypertrophy) being a risk factor. Also, my friend Priya, who is a nurse, said ECGs (electrocardiograms) are vital for quick detection. Also, I heard that medication like "Atorvastatin 40mg" helps in keeping cholesterol under check.
normalised: Now, I am no doctor, but I have been doing some reading up on this stuff. Apparently, there are different types of heart problems. Some are genetic, some are caused by lifestyle, and some are just plain bad luck. I saw something about "L-V-H" (Left Ventricular Hypertrophy) being a risk factor. Also, my friend Priya, who is a nurse, said E-C-G-s (electrocardiograms) are vital for quick detection. Also, I heard that medication like "Atorvastatin forty milligram" helps in keeping cholesterol under check.

unnormalised: So, what can we do, right? Well, I’m trying to cut down on oily food and maybe even prepone the evening chai to some herbal tea. Small steps, you know? And maybe getting BP checked quarterly will help too. Also, going for a walk for a few days a week can also improve the overall situation, right? I've also started using a fitness tracker to monitor my steps and heart rate. It’s not a magic bullet, but every little bit helps.

I have also started using a fitness tracker to monitor my steps and heart rate. It is not a magic bullet, but every little bit helps.

unnormalised: Bottom line is, don't take your heart for granted. Get checked, eat well (as much as possible!), and try to manage stress. This Diwali, maybe skip the extra mithai and opt for a healthy snack instead. Your heart will thank you for it. And tell your loved ones to do the same. After all, life is too short to spend it worrying about clogged arteries!
